soc.message

Class SOCBankTrade

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCBankTrade
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, SOCMessageForGame

    public class SOCBankTrade
extends SOCMessage
implements SOCMessageForGame
    This request to server means that a player wants to trade with the bank or a port. Or, an info announcement from server of a successful bank/port trade (version 2.0.00 or higher) sent after the SOCPlayerElement messages which announce the resource changes. Clients older than v2.0.00 ignore this message from server; use SOCStringManager.VERSION_FOR_I18N.

    If the client's trade request is acceptable, server responds to entire game with:

    • SOCPlayerElements to clients older than v2.4.50 (VERSION_FOR_SKIP_PLAYERELEMENTS): A SOCPlayerElement.LOSE for each resource type being traded in, then SOCPlayerElement.GAIN for those given to the player.
    • This SOCBankTrade to announce the trade details to clients v2.0.00 or higher; older clients are sent a SOCGameTextMsg instead.
    The server disallows any unacceptable trade by sending the client a SOCRejectOffer with a reason code like SOCRejectOffer.REASON_NOT_YOUR_TURN. Servers before v2.4.50 (SOCRejectOffer.VERSION_FOR_REPLY_REASONS) sent an explanatory SOCGameServerText instead.

    To undo a bank trade in version 1.1.13 or higher, the player's client can send another BANKTRADE message with the same resources but give/get swapped. For instance, if they gave 3 sheep to get 1 brick, undo by sending a BANKTRADE to give 1 brick to get 3 sheep.

    Author:
    Robert S. Thomas
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCBankTrade

        public SOCBankTrade(java.lang.String ga,
                    SOCResourceSet give,
                    SOCResourceSet get,
                    int pn)
        Create a BankTrade message.
        Parameters:
        ga - the name of the game
        give - the set of resources being given to the bank/port: see getGiveSet()
        get - the set of resources being taken from the bank/port: see getGetSet()
        pn - the player number making the trade, or -1 to send a request from client. Field not sent if -1. Versions older than 2.0.00 ignore this field.

    • Method Detail

      • getGame

        public java.lang.String getGame()
        Description copied from interface: SOCMessageForGame
        Name of game this message is for, if any. Must not be null in a message sent to the server: If message is not about per-game structures or code, use SOCMessage.GAME_NONE.

        At the server, the message treater dispatches incoming SOCMessageForGames based on their getGame():

        • null: Message is ignored
        • SOCMessage.GAME_NONE: Message is handled by SOCServer itself or SOCServerMessageHandler
        • Any other game name: Looks for a game with that name, to dispatch to the GameHandler for that game's type. If no game with that name is found, the message is ignored.
        Specified by:
        getGame in interface SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        the name of the game

      • getGiveSet

        public SOCResourceSet getGiveSet()
        Get the set of resources being given by the player to the bank or port.
        Returns:
        the set of resources being given

      • getGetSet

        public SOCResourceSet getGetSet()
        Get the set of resources being received by the player from the bank or port.
        Returns:
        the set of resources being taken

      • getPlayerNumber

        public int getPlayerNumber()
        In a message from server, get the player number who made the bank trade. In a message from client, get -1 because this field isn't set. Versions older than 2.0.00 ignore this field. Versions older than 2.4.50 don't recognize reply reason codes (< -1).
        Returns:
        the player number or negative reason code (message from server), or -1 if not set (message from client).

      • toCmd

        public java.lang.String toCmd()
        Build a command string to send this message. playerNumber is not sent if -1.
        Specified by:

        Returns:

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String message)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String).
        Parameters:
        message - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Specified by:
        toString in class SOCMessage
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
